clinical_study.brief_title: A Hospital-based Postnatal Parent Education Intervention About Infant Immunizations
clinical_study.official_title: Immunizing Infants Against Pain: a Hospital-based Postnatal Parent Education Intervention About Infant Immunizations

oversight_info.authority: Canada: Mount Sinai Hospital Research Ethics Board
Canada: University of Toronto Health Sciences Research Ethics Board

brief_summary.textblock: Immunization injections are the most common recurring painful medical procedure undertaken in childhood. Numerous evidence-based and feasible interventions are available to mitigate immunization pain, however, there is low uptake of these interventions in clinical practice, revealing a knowledge-to-care gap between what is known about pain and pain management. This is a 4-year single-centre, randomized, parallel 3-group add-on trial that will enrol 3042 mothers hospitalized following the birth of an infant at Mount Sinai Hospital (MSH) in Toronto. The trial will evaluate and compare the impact of two levels of intensity of maternal education about pain management during infant immunizations ('low': pamphlet vs. 'high': pamphlet + video) compared to placebo control after the birth of an infant on maternal behaviour during future infant immunizations at up to 6 months of age (i.e., use of analgesic interventions), maternal knowledge and attitudes about pain and pain management up to 6 months after birth. In addition, this trial will compare a pamphlet given to the low and high intensity groups after 12 months compared to placebo control on maternal behaviour during future infant immunizations at up to 18 months of age, maternal knowledge, attitudes about pain and pain management, immunization compliance and incidence of needle fear in children.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.description: Parent self-reported use of any of the 3 most effective analgesic interventions (breastfeeding, sugar water, or topical anesthetics) at infant immunization; the specific time period for the outcome assessment is at either 2, 4 or 6 month infant immunization, based on a random allocation process, and again at 18 months.

secondary_outcome.description: Parent knowledge about effective analgesic interventions for mitigating pain at infant immunization; the specific time period for the outcome assessment is at either 2, 4 or 6 month infant immunization, based on a random allocation process, and again at 18 months.

Parent self-reported attitudes about pain/pain management at infant immunization; the specific time period for the outcome assessment is at either 2, 4 or 6 month infant immunization, based on a random allocation process, and again at 18 months.

Parent self-reported utilization of specific analgesic interventions at infant immunization; the specific time period for the outcome assessment is at either 2, 4 or 6 month infant immunization, based on a random allocation process, and again at 18 months.
Parent self-reported compliance with infant immunization schedule, validated by health care provider, at 18 months of age.
Parent self-reported presence of needle fear in their children at 18 months of age.

other_outcome.description: Parent self-reported attempted (and failed) use of any of the 3 most effective analgesic interventions (breastfeeding, sugar water, or topical anesthetics) at infant immunization; the specific time period for the outcome assessment is at either 2, 4, or 6 month infant immunization, based on a random allocation process, and again at 18 months.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- mothers rooming in with infants on postnatal ward
Exclusion Criteria:
- mothers with significant psychiatric conditions
- mothers unable to communicate in English
- mothers sharing room whereby another mother already participated
